question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of different gender?
inference:
There are 10 ways to choose a boy president and 10 ways to choose a girl vice-president.  There are also 10 ways to choose a girl president and 10 ways to choose a boy vice-president.  So, there are a total of \(10 \times 10 + 10 \times 10 = 200\) ways to choose a president and vice-president of different genders.
Final Answer: \boxed{200}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 10 members of the opposite sex. The answer is $20\times 10=\boxed{200}$.
